review_title: Felt so taken care of here
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: My 5 years at FFYC I always felt like a valued employee. My supervisors and team were always very understanding and supportive. Learned so much and became a very skilled clinician!
cons: I left for something new!

job_title: Facilitator in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible schedule, work from home, work life balance. Great benefits and PTO
cons: Not much room for growth, pay could be better.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in San Mateo, CA
pros: Flexible, Good work environment and good cause.
cons: Low pay, a lot of driving and documentation.

job_title: Program Specialist in Oakland, CA
pros: Great support when there are enough members on team
cons: Unfortunately very high turnover with little to no guidance with training new staff. Low pay for the amount of work given

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: If you need to finish your clinical hours, this could be the spot. The youth really need more mental health clinicians, parent partners ect.
cons: Took a pay cut to finish my clinical hours. Was told I would get a good amount of therapy children/youth hours. This was not the case. Need more diversity in upper management. Clinicians should get more substance use training. Youth also use drugs and alcohol.

review_title: Great experience, no help from clinical
job_title: Residential Youth Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great experience, friendly staff to work with
cons: Clinical doesn’t help clients. Wfh and don’t reach out to them. Leaving RYC to do everything

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: There are literally no pros to working here.
cons:
Got in trouble with CCL (look on county site) for failing to call 911 for AN HOUR. Grossly negligent safety issues for staff and residents. Management sits in an ivory tower and practices vindictive, illegal and unethical behavior with subordinates and residents. Out of touch with the reality younger generations currently experience. You will get physically attacked here and you will experience environmental grossly negligent safety risks. STRTPs are becoming a political hotbed because they are dangerous to begin with, and this one is grossly mismanaged which culminates numerous safety risks. STRTPs are currently taking the place of locked facilities because CA refuses to turn and face the music that locked facilities are the appropriate level of care for this population. The verbal abuse and harassment, assault and battery, assault with potentially deadly weapons (that residents shouldn’t even have access to), extreme property destruction (including staff cars), and runaways are out of control. It’s dangerous for everyone involved. There is a lot of turnover for a reason. 
Some school staff at the school bullies students and staff, exhibiting the exact behavior students/residents are there to correct. Management enables this behavior and gaslights anyone who calls attention to it. At one point a chair was placed OUTSIDE of an office to sit in when attempted to address these issues. Constant examples of grown men in management positions acting like vindictive teenagers and creating a hostile work environment. All management are male. Workload is unmanageable to top it off!

job_title: Associate Marriage and Family Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: Good supervision Helpful co workers Training opportunities Manageable caseload
cons: School based services felt isolating at times.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: Great clients, flexible hours, compassionate coworkers
cons: Low pay, leadership is disorganized, challenging work life balance

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Alameda, CA
pros: Amazing hiring staff that makes you feel welcome from day one. Always keeping you up-to-date on the hiring process.
cons: Must follow CA hiring guidelines and sometimes the background check can take a bit. This not Fred Finch issues, it’s the states issue.

job_title: AMFT, Mental Health Clinician in Oakland, CA
pros: Team-based atmosphere; Focus & support of self-care & professional development; Referral compensation, hiring bonus & for some programs a stay-on incentive; Can move around within the agency; Free training opportunities provided; Opportunities for advanced trainings such as EMDR and DBT; Good benefits (401k matching); Restorative/Racial Justice Initiative; Staff awards; Supervision provided
cons: Pay is decent but cost of living can cause need for higher pay and possibly need to get a side hustle or second job unless you have a good junk saved or a two person income/household; Paperwork, county & funding resource guidelines, expectations & changes can be challenging & draining. Because of this some programs struggle to keep people on past 1 to 1.5 years as they realize it can be overwhelming especially w/out prior experience

review_title: A great job for gaining experience
job_title: RBT
pros: Good training, supervisors were helpful, and it's a rewarding job.
cons: None, it was a good experience

job_title: Residential Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: Free food that’s about it
cons: Insensitive people outdated unorganized mess

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Working with youth. Great opportunity for hands on experience.
cons: Always underpaid and overworked. Low staffing for residential.

job_title: Instructional Aide in Vacaville, CA
pros: great staff, good therapists, nice facilities
cons: low salary, no professional development opportunities

review_title: I felt very supported by staff but pay falls short compared to other companies
job_title: Behavior Technician in San Diego, CA
pros:
Supervisors are great
I felt supported by all staff
Very inclusive and understanding work environment
Offer scholarships to college students who apply
Flexible in the sense that all cases are confirmed by you before they are added to your schedule
If you perform well, you
cons:
The pay for behavior technicians falls short of other companies.
I have other friends that work for other companies and I am the lowest paid out of all of them

review_title: There are ups and downs, like most employers
job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Allowed to be creative, not micro managed, trusted
cons: Lack of accountability, staff are overworked

review_title: Good for developing clinical skills and getting experience
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: Supervision (I had a great supervisor. Not all were), positive supportive culture, gratifying work
cons: Low pay, challenging populations, and high paperwork demands lead to burnout

review_title: Decent entry level job if looking into social/mental services
job_title: CFT Facilitator in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule and lots of exposure to CPS world.
cons: Heavy CPS cases from time to time

job_title: Clinical Behavior Supervisor in Temecula, CA
pros: Team environment, friendly staff, everyone cares about their jobs
cons: Turnover rate, one person does 5 different jobs, inconsistencies with direct care staff, low pay

job_title: Behavioral Technician in Riverside, CA
pros: The company has two weeks of paid training and drive time.
cons:
*Drive time pay too low for long drives 
* will hire you in riverside but will only have cases in Temecula/San Diego.
* will give you 30 minutes to drive to the next Clint which is an hour a way plus traffic

job_title: CFT Facilitator in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits, competitive pay, hours & holidays off! Management really seems to listen & care about staff retention. We mostly make our own schedules.
cons: Pay raises aren’t much, but better than nothing!

job_title: Residential Youth Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros:
On-call has no benefits, but you make your own schedule.
Some staff are amazing and truly care about the kids
Flexible hours because they are opened 24-7
cons:
Low pay for high end work
Constant understaffing issues
Not enough training for the population that you work with
Can quickly burn you out.

job_title: Program Specialist in Oakland, CA
pros: Great staff and community. Communication with changes also includes more support
cons: Often so much change it leads to burnout. Low pay

review_title: Great mission and people.  Too much administrative BS.
job_title: Program Director in Oakland, CA
pros: Great people to work with at all levels of the agency. Excellent mission.
cons: Tight nonprofit budgets lead to more work for less pay. Documentation requirements tend to burn people out who really want to be spending their time providing direct services.

review_title: This place could be run much better
job_title: Residential Youth Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good Benefits, good program for the kids, and good coworkers.
cons: Low starting wage. Low yearly raise. You have to work on weekends.

job_title: Director of Facilities in Oakland, CA
pros: Amazing leadership & staff with great benefits to match!
cons: I have no cons to share.

job_title: Family Partner in San Diego, CA
pros: Love the management and the work environment. All co workers are very friendly and understanding. There is an amazing work/life balance. Self care is taken seriously.
cons: Some cases are very tough to handle. A lot of crisis for the department I work in.

job_title: Facilitator in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible schedule, great support and vacation hours with benefits
cons: Doesn’t get to see the outcome of meetings

job_title: Program Director in Oakland, CA
pros: The organization is addressing racial inequity and systemic racism.
cons: It is a lot of work and it may feel overwhelming at times.

review_title: poor pay, management does not have your back
job_title: Residential Youth Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: if you truly enjoy the type of work, and the demographic you are working with, the work can be extremely rewarding
cons: horrible pay, high turnover rate, HR will protect their own, thank goodness for the Union

job_title: Associate Marriage and Family Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: I loved working here! The people and supervisors were great! I learned a lot from both them and the work with my clients
cons: You will definitely work extremely hard

review_title: Poor pay, except for the top level exec staff of course.
job_title: Lcsw in Alameda, CA
pros: They will take almost anyone because they have to keep hiring to fill the constant turnover. Get your hours here if you must & then run!
cons: People with masters degrees making poor salaries. For years we heard how the management leaders were taking a look at this & working on a way to address it. But no change, in fact, insultingly low wages weren't enough. Working 50-hour weeks is a given if you want to meet productivity requirements, so in all reality, an even worse average salary. More turnover in the clinicians role than I've ever seen anywhere else, & yet they continue to act as if this is the norm & to be expected. Retention of quality employees is not a priority unless it pads the exec staff's pocketbooks.  Also, after hearing recently from a former coworker who told me employees were asked to pay for their own tickets to a staff appreciation dinner, it was just more confirmation that moving on to Kaiser was the smartest thing I did. Fred Finch, this is the Bay Area- you are dealing with some of the most educated, savvy proponents of social justice, who believe in the services we provide for those who so dearly need them. Stop treating these same employees as if they haven't got a clue & should just be grateful for whatever you scrape up to give them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Riverside, CA
pros: Approachable and friendly leadership team that supports the training of entry level RBTS.
cons: Part time schedule still requires 5 days a week due to sparse sessions

job_title: RBT
pros: organized and very persistent with goals
cons: bad communication at times for the most part

job_title: Facilitator in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible work hours. Great benefits.
cons: There is no upward mobility available.

job_title: Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: Get hours towards licensure, experience, work with nice people
cons: salary management productivity and too many meetings

review_title: Just say no to Fred Finch!!!!
job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Oakland, CA
pros: There are none. Do not trust this agency!!! They hired me away from a huge non-profit and then rescinded my offer after making no explanations during the offer period. My life is on hold due to their unprofessional and unethical behavior.
cons: Fred Finch hired me away from a full-time job as a clinician. They promised a higher salaray in the hiring process and then hours later took adverse action because of a moviing violation on my MVA record. The job offer was made over the phone and had no preconditinals. I had already left my job because of their offer and turnedd down other offerrs. When trying to communicate with the organization, HR and the clinical staff ignored me completely. They left a VM that my offer was rescinded. They knew I left a job for them, and this are guilty of fraudulent inducement. Their behavior was reprehensible. I'm now unemployed, have no health insurance and I'm looking at foreclosure. They loved my outstanding resume and qualifications, and then put me out like the trash with no thought to the personal and professional ramifications of their actions.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Spring Valley, CA
pros:
-Great benefits: 401k, 6 hours of paid vacation every two weeks
-The co workers are awesome, great energy and work as a team to get the job done. 
~good on your resume
~ recommend only working a year for this company
cons:
~Get little or no help from upper management. Over work for little pay that is a slap in the face. ~Understaff most times when dealing with at risk youth, so there will be times that it will be 2 staff with 6 kids.
~There is little or no room for advancement 
~Working weekends 

~They focus more on medicating the children than anything, if you mess up on administrating medication then more likely you will be fired on the first mistake. You are number and expendable
~upper management hates when you question them, they prefer people who are a yes man that follow the rules and don't say or question anything.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros:
-Some flexibility to be able to try new things
-Beautiful Oakland Campus
-Friendly coworkers
-Ample opportunities for professional development
cons:
-Pay is not the best (but also not the worst)
-Some particular ideas/ways of approaching things seem to be deeply ingrained in this org, perhaps because it has been around for so long. While there is a certain amount of flexibility for positive change, at times it feels that we are being held back.
-I don't feel very connected to what's going on in the overall organization/not sure where we're headed
-Some equipment & space that we work with (computers, storage/office space, etc.) is not the best. Although, we are able to get by with what we have.

review_title: Means well but that doesn't mean it pays well...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros: Like most non-profits that have existed longer than 50 years, FFYC has embedded itself in Northern and Southern California and should be seen as invaluable to the communities they serve. They have a great mission statement and mean it. They are ever evolving to face the shifting landscapes of social service work. There are tons of great people who work for the agency. If you're fresh out of grad school and looking for your first "real" job, FFYC has the training grounds for you.
cons: Typical non-profit in that they squeeze the most work out of employees for the bare minimum of pay. And when workers are overworked, underpaid, and not appreciated, burnout prevails and communities suffer. Unfortunately it can be a typical revolving door at FFYC especially front line staff. Expect a co-pay for benefits.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: Great experience if you ate just starting out in the mental health field. Residential has some of the most passionate, caring people you'll ever meet. My supervisors are amazing at New Yosemite and really support staff.
cons:
Pay is ridiculous and is constantly "being looked at" but never changed. The amount of work and safety risk in residential deserves a livable wage. We shouldn't have to work 50 hours a week just to be able to pay the bills. 

Upper level management and the CEO don't seem to care and seem insincere.

review_title: Consistent turn over due to high burn out
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Oakland, CA
pros:
Few supervisors who are supportive and take feedback well.
Great efforts in working towards cultural competency.
Great practice in comprehensive documentation.
cons:
Management is will to listen to feedback and yet makes little effort to put into action.
Negligent in its treatment towards clinicians who are continually traumatized secondarily. Little put in place to provide clinicians with needed support.
Company is working from a place of traumatization and has difficulty seeing blind spots. 
Too much focus on paperwork which contributes to high burn out as well as less focus on clinical work. 
Work culture is extremely negative and does not foster growth and expansion.

review_title: Too much change for little pay
job_title: Help Desk in Oakland, CA
pros: Nice people and beautiful campus. Learn alot really fast. Good information and trainings for the most part. Nice benefits if you are only looking to enroll in the bare minimum. Great work experience to carry elsewhere for more pay.
cons:
Way too much turnover. It is an IT nightmare and very stressful to keep up with equipment. Regressive technology for the most part, but its getting better. Although, you learn alot, you stress a whole lot as well. It is literally sink or swim. 

Pay is too low to keep people. Upper management can be a bit stuck up. Would only advise this job for beginners looking to gain experience.

review_title: Has been a solid employer over the years that has become a great one in recent years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: In the last year or two leadership changes at the top level has brought Fred Finch from a good employer to a great one. Upper management leads by example with their work ethic, clinical skills, and sincerity. the agency offers good programs and is always trying to improve.  Folks are here because they want to be which translates into good services for kids and families.  Good benefits for a nonprofit and generous paid time off.
cons: Salaries are non profit salaries - it's just a fact of life.

review_title: supportive supervisor, thoughtful and caring colleagues
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros: My supervisor has a lot of wisdom, and a lot of the other supervisors seem to also.  There is a lot of training on site.  If you stay a while, you can get a lot of paid time off, and the benefits are pretty good for a nonprofit.  Upper management is very accessible. I really like my colleagues. They often promote from within.
cons: The clients served are very challenging and that can be very stressful.  Also, there is a lot of documentation required.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros:
- Good experience for entry level people
- Benefits are good: Great PTO Accrual, 401k matching, medical/dental is affordable (if single w/no dependents), hours toward licensure for direct service staff
- There are some great managers and supervisors
- Most employees really care about the work
- I was lucky to have some really supportive supervisors
cons:
- Pay is low and hard to live on in Bay Area
- Mixed bag of manager/supervisor competency (some really great managers and some really bad ones)
- Upper management and executives appear out of touch

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Oakland, CA
pros: Passionate co-workers and great benefits.
cons: Extremely high turnover rate. Management is very disorganized and often not on the same page, often telling people different expectations. The director actually asked us in a department meeting, to go online and submit a positive employee review because all of the reviews are so bad. Haha! Ridiculous. Company also presents themselves as “trauma informed”, which they  clearly are not.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros:
-Plenty of hours towards licensure
-Supportive coworkers and management
-Flexible schedule (you create your own)
-Plenty of training
-Mixture of clientele will give you great experience
-Great benefits
cons:
-Meeting minimum requirements of weekly productivity hours is difficult (e.g., putting in a 50-60 hour work week for salaried 40 hour pay)
-Mediocre pay
-Cases are distributed to clinicians based upon immediate need (as they should), but this can sometimes lead to one clinician being overwhelmed with extremely difficult clients. Others may get the "luck of the draw" and get fewer clients with further distances.

review_title: Good place to learn then move on
job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Oakland, CA
pros:
On-site training center = free CEUs
In-house supervision for licensing
Some teams get along well and support one another
Annual raise is usually 3%, good benefits and extra money for health purposes
cons:
No merit-based raises
Many open positions means you are often doing more than just your job
Job satisfaction depends greatly on team culture 
Middle management are not great communicators
Once you are licensed, you are too expensive to keep so most people move on

job_title: Residential Youth Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: Everyone is friendly, the children can be so sweet and inspirational, there is great support from coworkers, the job can be pretty easy when times are calm, free food and entertainment (like movies, bowling, etc with the kids), plenty of opportunity for overtime (yay double pay!)
cons: The pay is somewhat low - it's increased now and that's good but it's still too low for the Bay Area

job_title: Manager in Oakland, CA
pros: Staff is very committed. CEO open to new ideas, less deficit focused ( can be a problem at non- profits). Good clinical work being done.
cons: Not many. Managers vary in terms of paying attention to morale, but generally care ( and not much they can do abt the reams of county required paperwork.)

job_title: Marriage and Family Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: Flexibility and freedom in the work. Great experience. What you learn you take with you and almost anything is easier.
cons: Really challenging work, trainings are boring and don't add value. I felt like I was running around a lot all the time trying to get things done. Everything is hard including the paperwork, productivity requirements.

review_title: Think again about working at non-profits
job_title: in Oakland, CA
pros:
- they are really flexible with giving you time off
- everyone is kind and easy to communicate with 
- generally a low-stress environment
cons:
- compensation is poor
- there are a lot of incompetent people working there
- not intellectually stimulating 
- not challenging

job_title: Clinician in Oakland, CA
pros: Challenging work makes for excellent learning opportunities for those who want to step up. Some great co-workers, some people trying really hard to support clients.Decent PTO and benefits. Good place to accrue hours if you are a recent grad working towards license.
cons: Management as a whole is terrible, there are a few exceptions but the pass the buck culture is truly toxic. Always asked to take on more than your role, very little appreciation or acknowledgment expressed. Turnover is high because people get overworked, underpaid and burnt out. The pay is very poor.

review_title: Needs to work on compensation and treating employees like they are valued
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros:
-small, family atmosphere
-most people are nice
cons:
-some people are incompetent - you get what you pay for
-others are very competent and underpaid for their years of experience and qualifications
-finally institutes a performance review process and then no one gets a raise

review_title: Not the best place to work.
job_title: Mental Health Resource Specialist in Oakland, CA
pros: Compared to other facilities, there are less requirements. You have time to socialize because you do not have to monitor teens as much.
cons: The management is incompetent. The management has made comments about not socializing with line staff. The management is not about improving the program. The program does not help the kids. Restraints are wild. a lot of money wasted.

job_title: School Based Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: For pre-licensed clinicians a great place to learn and train in medi-cal billing practices. There is a salary bump for every year you stay at the company.
cons: Starting salary is low for the amount of work that is expected.

review_title: Good place to gain hours toward licensure
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Oakland, CA
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, can work from home at times, hours are somewhat flexible (you manage your own caseload)
cons: Long hours, lots of driving

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros: Supportive line staff presence. Good pto and Healthcare
cons: Divide between upper management and linestaff. Pay is very low for the work and clientele you work with. High turnover rate.

review_title: Great Place to get your Clinical Hours

buildings are old - non-profit looking

review_title: Hard work with a challenging population
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The leadership team is extremely supportive. Tom, the CEO, is an amazing leader.
cons: Accountability is not held all through the agency which forces some of us to work harder than others.

Personally, I had a very good supervisor - not all programs did.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: One of the best people to work with that are patient and caring for the participants.

job_title: Family Support Specialist in San Diego, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
